abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To understand the mechanisms of antagonistic coevolution, it is crucial to identify the genetics of parasite resistance. In the <jats:italic>Daphnia magna</jats:italic>–<jats:italic>Pasteuria ramosa</jats:italic> host–parasite system, the most important step of the infection process is the one in which <jats:italic>P. ramosa</jats:italic> spores attach to the host’s foregut. A matching-allele model (MAM) describes the host–parasite genetic interactions underlying attachment success. Here we describe a new <jats:italic>P. ramosa</jats:italic> genotype, P15, which, unlike previously studied genotypes, attaches to the host’s hindgut, not to its foregut. Host resistance to P15 attachment shows great diversity across natural populations. In contrast to <jats:italic>P. ramosa</jats:italic> genotypes that use foregut attachment, P15 shows some quantitative variation in attachment success and does not always lead to successful infections, suggesting that hindgut attachment represents a less-efficient infection mechanism than foregut attachment. Using a Quantitative Trait Locus (QTL) approach, we detect two significant QTLs in the host genome: one that co-localizes with the previously described <jats:italic>D. magna</jats:italic> PR locus of resistance to foregut attachment, and a second, major QTL located in an unlinked genomic region. We find no evidence of epistasis. Fine mapping reveals a genomic region, the D locus, of ~13 kb. The discovery of a second <jats:italic>P. ramosa</jats:italic> attachment site and of a novel host-resistance locus increases the complexity of this system, with implications for both for the coevolutionary dynamics (e.g., Red Queen and the role of recombination), and for the evolution and epidemiology of the infection process.</jats:p>
